Western Academy of Beijing (WAB) Overview

The Western Academy of Beijing (WAB) is an independent, non-profit international day school located in the Lai Guang Ying area of the Chaoyang District in Beijing, China. It was established in 1994 and therefore has over 30 years of history. The school accommodates students of all ages, from Nursery/Pre-K (Early Years) through Grade 12 (high school).

History and Achievements

WAB opened its doors on September 1, 1994, starting with 149 students in a renovated factory space. The school has achieved several milestones over the years:

  • In 1997, Jane Goodall visited the school, initiating a lasting partnership with Roots & Shoots.
  • By 2001, WAB moved to a purpose-built campus, adding new wings and facilities over the years.
  • The HUB, a support center for arts, sciences, and sports, opened in 2005.
  • In 2006, WAB launched its outdoor program, "WAB Wild," and the school was also named a Model School of Olympic Education.

The school celebrated its first graduation in 2007 and gained APAC membership in 2008. It continues to make strides in sustainability efforts, and was named an Apple Distinguished School in 2013. More recent updates include adding clean air systems, creating a new Swiss School section in 2017, restoring Duck Lake, and holding FOEN conferences.

The school managed to transition smoothly to global remote learning during the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, and renovated its campus in 2021 to promote flexible learning. WAB celebrated its 30th anniversary with community celebrations in 2024.

WAB Wild Outdoor Learning Program

A notable feature of the WAB educational experience is the WAB Wild outdoor learning program. This program immerses students into nature, emphasizing environmental understanding and fostering independence. Activities are tailored for each grade level and involve a variety of skill-building activities, including rock-climbing, abseiling, kayaking, canoeing, radio communication, and rescue training.

Students engage in multi-day expeditions and use the environment as a classroom for subjects like science and geography. The Miao Liang Environmental Education Center, which is sited in the Mi Yun mountains on the Bai He River, facilitates programs for Grades 6–12, encompassing environmental science, team-building, and sustainability studies.

The educational offerings are age-specific, with Grade 5 students attending a transition camp that helps them prepare for middle school, while high school students have the opportunity to participate in the Duke of Edinburgh Award Adventurous Journey, exhibiting leadership, teamwork, and resilience.
